answer_html: Plugging in values tells us that \(\frac{ds}{dt} = f'(t) < 0\) on the interval \({\color{blue} t \in (2,5)}\), where \(t\) is in seconds as stated above.
answer_latex:
Plugging in values tells us that $\frac{ds}{dt} = f'(t) < 0$ on the
interval ${\color{blue} t \in (2,5)}$, where $t$ is in seconds as
stated above.
hints_html:
When the particle is moving in the negative direction (backwards), what function of time is negative? (It is not position!)

What is the definition of the velocity function? How does it relate to the position function?
hints_latex:
What is the definition of the velocity function? How does it relate to
the position function?
hints_raw:
When the particle is moving in the ''negative direction'' (backwards), what function of time is ''negative''? (It is not position!)
What is the definition of the velocity function? How does it relate to the position function?
question: 3 (b)
sols_html:
When the particle is moving in the negative direction, its velocity is negative. Therefore we must look for the \(t\) for which \(\frac{ds}{dt} = f'(t) < 0\):

\[\begin{aligned} s &= t^3 - \frac{21}{2}t^2 + 30t \\ \frac{ds}{dt} &= 3t^2 - 21t + 30\end{aligned}\]

Setting the derivative (i.e., the velocity function) equal to zero, we obtain \(\displaystyle 0 = 3t^2 - 21t + 30 = 3(t-2)(t-5)\). Hence the velocity is zero when \(\displaystyle t = 2,\,5\).

Plugging in values tells us that \(\frac{ds}{dt} = f'(t) < 0\) on the interval \({\color{blue} t \in (2,5)}\), where \(t\) is in seconds as stated above.
sols_latex:
When the particle is moving in the \emph{negative direction}, its
velocity is \emph{negative}. Therefore we must look for the $t$ for
which $\frac{ds}{dt} = f'(t) < 0$:

\begin{align*}
s &= t^3 - \frac{21}{2}t^2 + 30t
\\ \frac{ds}{dt} &= 3t^2 - 21t + 30
\end{align*}

Setting the derivative (i.e., the velocity function) equal to zero, we
obtain $\displaystyle 0 = 3t^2 - 21t + 30 = 3(t-2)(t-5)$. Hence the
velocity is zero when $\displaystyle t = 2,\,5$.

Plugging in values tells us that $\frac{ds}{dt} = f'(t) < 0$ on the
interval ${\color{blue} t \in (2,5)}$, where $t$ is in seconds as
stated above.
sols_raw:
When the particle is moving in the ''negative direction'', its velocity is ''negative''. Therefore we must look for the <math>t</math> for which <math>\frac{ds}{dt} = f'(t) < 0 </math>:

:<math>
\begin{align}
s &= t^3 - \frac{21}{2}t^2 + 30t
\\ \frac{ds}{dt} &= 3t^2 - 21t + 30
\end{align}
</math>

<br>Setting the derivative (i.e., the velocity function) equal to zero, we obtain <math>\displaystyle 0 = 3t^2 - 21t + 30 = 3(t-2)(t-5)</math>. Hence the velocity is zero when <math>\displaystyle t = 2,\,5</math>.

Plugging in values tells us that <math>\frac{ds}{dt} = f'(t) < 0 </math> on the interval <math>{\color{blue} t \in (2, 5)}</math>, where <math>t</math> is in seconds as stated above.
statement_html:
Short-Answer Question. Simplify your answer as much as possible and show your work.

Let \(\displaystyle s = f(t) = t^3 - \frac{21}2t^2 + 30t\) be the position function of a particle that is moving in a straight line, where t is measured in seconds and s in metres. When is the particle moving in the negative direction?
statement_raw:
'''Short-Answer Question. Simplify your answer as much as possible and show your work.'''

Let <math>\displaystyle s = f(t) = t^3 - \frac{21}2t^2 + 30t</math> be the position function of a particle that is moving in a straight line, where ''t'' is measured in seconds and ''s'' in metres. When is the particle moving in the negative direction?
